ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Audiometry reveals a moderate-to-profound sloping sensorineural hearing loss with symmetrical bone conduction thresholds.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Psychosocial and emotional reaction to hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient exhibits significant anger, frustration, and paranoia (believing family tells secrets) resulting from communication breakdown.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To determine the degree, type, and configuration of hearing loss.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities, particularly given the patient's complaints of clarity.
To evaluate middle ear function and acoustic reflex thresholds.
To assess the patient's self-perceived handicap and identify specific communication goals (HHIE, COSI).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation reveals a bilateral moderate-to-profound sensorineural hearing loss. A critical finding is the extremely poor word recognition ability (20-24%), which has significantly declined from the previous assessment 2 years prior. Middle ear function is normal. The patient's presentation is complicated by severe psychosocial issues, including anger and mistrust of family members, necessitating a focus on rehabilitation beyond just amplification.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: moderately severe to profound SNHL (PTA 65 dB HL). Left ear: moderate to profound SNHL (PTA 66 dB HL). Sloping configuration.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT: 75 dB HL (Right), 65 dB HL (Left). WRS: 20% (Right) and 24% (Left) at reduced SL due to recruitment. Very poor scores.

tests.name: Immittance
tests.result_summary: Type A tympanograms bilaterally. Acoustic reflexes absent bilaterally.

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.result_summary: HHIE and COSI administered to assist in intervention planning.

counseling_actions: Counsel patient and family on the emotional impact of hearing loss (anger, frustration)
Address the patient's paranoia ('secret telling') as a symptom of communication breakdown
Discuss realistic expectations given the poor word recognition scores
Encourage family participation in rehabilitation to learn facilitative strategies

escalation.rationale_short: Immediate focus is on psychosocial rehabilitation and communication strategies due to the patient's resistance and anger; medical referral not indicated as urgent despite WRS drop.

follow_up_plan.objective: Complete group rehabilitation program and reassess readiness for amplification.

expected_outcome: Speechreading activity: Performance improved from 0 out of 10 to 9 out of 10 correct by the final session.
Patient attitude: Shifted from anger and resistance to confidence; patient began implementing communication strategies and interacting more freely with family.
Family dynamic: Wife reported significant improvement, stating it was the 'best thing to happen since he was diagnosed'; anger no longer ruled communication.
Plan: Patient is scheduled for a hearing aid evaluation to determine if current technology provides benefit.
